question_text: A 29-year-old man is evaluated for the recent appearance of lesions on his tongue. The lesions are painless and cannot be scraped off with a tongue blade. He has HIV infection.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is oral hairy leukoplakia (Option D). Oral hairy leukoplakia is typically recognized by its occurrence on the lateral portions of the tongue (although other oral sites may also be involved) as white painless plaques that cannot be scraped off. Oral hairy leukoplakia is a manifestation of Epstein-Barr virus infection of the squamous epithelium of the tongue and is not considered to be premalignant. It is relatively specific for HIV infection but can also occur in other immunodeficiency states.
